filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of digital editions of Blake's Songs of Innocence Copy D from the Morgan Library and Museum, Copy O from the Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas, Copy Q from Syracuse University Library, and Copy S from the Cincinnati Art Museum.
Blake first published Innocence with thirty-one plates in 1789, the date on its title page. He appears to have printed twenty-three copies that year; three—possibly the first copies of Innocence printed—were in black ink on one side of the leaf, which remained uncolored (Copy U in the Archive is one of the three). Twenty were printed in green, yellow ochre, or raw sienna inks on both sides of octavo size leaves and finished in light watercolor washes. At least four of these were combined with copies of Songs of Experience, printed in 1794, to form Songs of Innocence and of Experience (Copies B-E). For these newly combined copies, Blake moved Plates 34–36 (“The Little Girl Lost” and “The Little Girl Found”) to Experience, leaving Innocence with twenty-eight plates. He moved Plates 53 (“The School Boy”) and 54 (“The Voice of the Ancient Bard”) to Experience in 1818.
Innocence Copy D, printed in 1789 in yellow ochre (with four plates in light brown or raw sienna ink) on both sides of the leaves, has thirty-one plates and is finished in light washes. Copy O, printed c. 1802 in raw sienna ink on one side of the leaves, has twenty-six impressions finished in light washes, pen and ink outlining, and page numbers in the upper right corner of the designs. Plates 6 and 7 (“The Ecchoing Green”), numbered 5 and 6 in this copy, were extracted and are not extant. Copy Q, printed c. 1804 in light orangish yellow ochre ink on one side of the leaves, has twenty-eight plates and is finished in delicate washes, pen and ink outlining, and page numbers in pencil. The texts of Plates 17 and 19 (“A Cradle Song” and “Holy Thursday”) were lightly printed and entirely rewritten in pen and brown watercolor. The untrimmed leaves of Plates 2 and 5 (frontispiece and “The Shepherd”) in Copy Q are included as supplementary images to show how the plates were originally registered to the paper. Copy S, mostly printed c. 1811 in light black ink on one side of the leaves, has twenty-eight plates and is finished in light washes and pen and ink page numbers. Plate 2, the frontispiece printed in green ink, was added to Copy S between 1920 and 1922; Plates 3, 4, 12, and 27, printed in shades of brown ink, are also from earlier printings.
Of these four copies of Innocence, only Copy D has ever been reproduced, by William Muir in a colored lithographic facsimile in 1885; the other copies have never been reproduced. With these copies, the Archive continues to realize its objective of publishing exemplary copies of each illuminated book from each of its printings and expanding the Blake canon by presenting works previously not available for study by the general public.
The Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable digital editions of 132 copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books. Users may view color corrected digital images of Blake's works at their true size, and enlarge and rotate these images to examine texts and illustrations in detail. The images are accompanied by diplomatic transcriptions and editors' notes, as well as illustration descriptions that make it possible to search Blake's works for visual motifs. The Archive also provides full bibliographic and provenance information for each digital edition it publishes.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

imprint.pubplace: LondonThe place of publication is not recorded in the volume, but Blake was living in London at the time of its composition, etching, and printing.

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 12.3 x 7.7 cm. and 10.9 x 6.3 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching, with some white-line etching, and hand coloringSee the Editors' Notes, Object 28 (Bentley Plate 21), for Blake's pen and ink overwriting of the text, including a textual variant in the final line of Object 28, the second plate of "Night."
objinfo.watermark: J WHATMAN | 1804 (Objects 3 and 19), EDMEADS & PINE 1802 (Objects 8 and 14).
objinfo.binding: Disbound and mounted in individual mats.Bound c. 1828 in green calf with two drawings on one leaf not by Blake; the drawings removed in 1964; disbound and the plates individually mounted in mats in 1995. Stab holes indicate that the frontispiece, Object 1 as arranged in this copy, was formerly bound facing the title page, Object 2.
objinfo.stabholes: Originally stabbed through three holes, 3.1 cm. from the top and 4.8 cm. and 4.4 cm. apart.

provenance.name: Syracuse University Library
provenance.note: Early history unknown; sold "the property of a lady," Sotheby's, 30 July 1893, lot 1100, with two drawings misattributed to Blake, Blake's letter to John Linnell of April(?) 1826, a "pen and ink signed portrait by J. Linnell, and a drawing of the portrait [of Blake] by Schiavonetti" (£49.10s. to the dealer Heath); acquired 1900 from the dealer Bernard Quaritch by Marsden J. Perry; William A. White by 1905; White's brother, Alfred T. White, no later than 1927; given by A. T. White to his daughter, Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen (nee Annie Jean White, 1888-1968), no later than 1964; deposited in the Syracuse University Library by Van Sinderen in 1964; bequeathed by Van Sinderen in 1968 to Syracuse University Library.

desc.objtitle:
Frontispiece to Songs of Innocence Songs of Innocence,
Object 1 (Bentley 2, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curly-haired partly nude male wearing semi-transparent colored tights, holding a musical pipe, walks toward the viewer with his left leg forward. This shepherd-piper looks up to the right at a cherubic nude male child floating in a horizontal position on a cloud or in an area of the sky. The child, with his arms raised horizontally and his legs spread, looks down at the piper. The plate is framed by trees on both sides whose leafy branches arch across the top. Behind the piper are grazing sheep and, in the background, more trees. A dark shadow appears in the lower right corner.

component.illusobjdesc: A dark shadow appears in the lower right corner.

A curly-haired partly nude male wearing semi-transparent colored tights, holding a musical pipe, strides toward the viewer with his left leg forward. His left arm is bent at the elbow. The body of this shepherd-piper faces forward but he looks up to the right at a cherubic male child.

A muscular but cherubic nude male child with short hair hovers in a horizontal position on a cloud or in an area of the sky above the head of a shepherd-piper. The child, with his arms raised horizontally and his legs spread, looks down at the piper. His genitals are pictured.
A cherubic male child hovers on a cloud or in an area of the sky above the shepherd-piper's head.
A flock of sheep grazes behind the shepherd-piper. Two in the front have their heads down.

Trees frame the plate on both sides. The tree on the left has a single trunk, while the two trees on the right intertwine. Their leafy branches form an arch overhead. There are more leafy trees in the background.
A male shepherd holds a musical pipe.

desc.objtitle:
Title Page,
Object 2 (Bentley 3, Erdman 3, Keynes 3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile facing right, a nurse or mother in a cap and long dress sits erect in a chair. In her lap she holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the left may be a boy with curly hair; the child on the right, with long hair, is probably a girl. To the right of the group is a large apple(?) tree bearing fruit; around the trunk loosely spirals a vine. Various small figures can be seen among the letters of the title, including a piper wearing a broad-brimmed hat standing in the crook of the first letter of "Innocence." Birds fly in the sky beneath and to the left of the "S" and above the "N" in "SONGS." Another bird flies upward above the first "n" of "Innocence."

component.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile facing right, a nurse or mother in a cap and long dress sits erect in a chair. In her lap she holds a book that two children read.
In her lap a nurse or mother holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the left may be a male with curly hair looking down at the book.

In her lap a nurse(?) holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the right, with long hair and wearing a gown, is probably a girl. Her left arm is bent at the elbow, with the forearm raised horizontally. Her left hand may be pointing to a passage in the book.
In her lap a nurse(?) holds an open book that two children read.
A nurse(?) sits in a chair that faces right.

To the right of the nurse(?) and two children is a large apple(?) tree, bearing fruit (around "of" in the title); around its trunk loosely spirals a vine. The upper leaves on the right of the tree reach near the flame-like vegetative motifs springing from the letters of "SONGS" (leafy extensions of the initial "S," the "N," and the terminal "S" are particularly extravagant).
There may be one or two trees on the horizon, just right of the trunk of the large tree.
In the "O" of "SONGS" is a kneeling figure with arms raised in a curve at about 135 degrees.
A tiny form, standing above the left vertical of the "N" of "SONGS," might be a figure with arms raised at 45 degrees.
A standing figure, perhaps with a wing leans against the middle stroke of the "N" of "SONGS." The figure may be looking down at and holding a book, reading or writing.
The figure leaning against the middle stroke of the "N" of "SONGS" may be holding a book.
A tiny gowned(?) female(?) figure with at least the left arm raised vertically stands, facing left, in the "G" of "SONGS."
A male piper(?) with a broad-brimmed hat and holding a pipe to his mouth, stands facing left and leaning against the "I" of "Innocence."
A bird flies in the sky beneath and to the left of the "S" in "SONGS."
A bird flies on extended wings above the "N" of "SONGS."
A bird flies upward above the first "n" of "Innocence."

The blue coloring of the background in the upper half of the plate indicates sky. The pink and yellow coloring surrounding "Innocence" may suggest sunrise or sunset. There may be low hills in the landscape.
Shadows cover the ground on each side of the tree.

of
Innocence
The Author & Printer WBlake

desc.objtitle:
Introduction,
Object 3 (Bentley 4, Erdman 4, Keynes 4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels (top left to bottom right): (1) two figures, both gowned, the front one seated; (2) a running, leaping, nude figure; (3) a standing figure, looking down at vegetation, possibly grain stems; (4) an indistinct figure, possibly looking down at an infant in a cradle; (5) at top right, a flying bird with vegetation, perhaps tree limbs and leaves above; (6) a seated figure facing the viewer with legs crossed, head resting on her(?) right hand, and perhaps holding an infant in her lap; (7) a solitary standing figure with three(?) flying birds; (8) two seated figures, probably gowned, facing to the right. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas. Dark shadows surround the vines' outer edges in the lower left corner and extend along the border toward the center of the plate. The background of the text is washed to suggest an area of sky and clouds along the top and side margins.

component.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins leafy vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils, some of them (top, bottom) loopy, that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas.
Dark shadows surround the vines' outer edges in the lower left corner and extend along the bottom border toward the center of the plate.

In the panel at top left there are two indistinct figures. The one in the foreground is gowned, seated, and facing right. The smaller figure to the right may be a standing child or a seated adult, again gowned.
In the second panel down from top left, a nude figure runs or leaps toward us with legs spread and arms raised to 135 degrees.

In the third panel down from top left is a standing figure with head lowered to look at some vegetation, possible grain stems. The human figure may be indulging in some sort of agricultural activity. The shape printed above the figure's head is indistinct in this copy; in other copies this might be a bird.
There is a standing figure in the panel lowest on the left, possibly looking down at an infant in a cradle.
There is a hooded cradle below and to the left of the standing figure(?) in the panel lowest on the left.
In the panel at top right is a bird flying with vegetation, perhaps the leafy branches of a tree, above and below.
In the panel at top right is a bird flying with vegetation, perhaps the leafy branches of a tree above and below.

In the second panel from top right is a seated figure, probably female, facing the viewer with legs crossed and head resting on her right hand. She may have long hair. An object, or perhaps an infant, rests in her lap.
In the second panel from top right is a seated figure facing the viewer. There may be an infant with its head at left in swaddling clothes resting in the seated figure's lap.

In the third panel from top right is a nude(?) solitary standing figure, perhaps indulging in some sort of agricultural activity, with three(?) birds flying near. The figure's left arm may be raised at just under 45 degrees.
There are three(?) birds flying above and to the right of the figure in the third panel from top right.
There are two seated figures in the lowest panel on the right, both facing left. They are both probably gowned. Leafy vegetation dangles above their heads.
The upper portion of the lowest panel on the right appears to be filled with vegetation of some sort.

The background of the text is washed to suggest an area of sky along the top and side margins and between some of the stanzas. Similar washes within the panels created by the vines help to unite these with the plate design. Some of these washes suggest sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Piping down the valleys wild
Piping songs of pleasant glee
On a cloud I saw a child.
And he laughing said to me.
Pipe a song about a Lamb
So I piped with merry chear,
Piper pipe that song again__
So I piped, he wept to hear.
Drop thy pipe thy happy pipe
Sing thy songs of happy chear.
So I sung the same again
While he wept with joy to hear
Piper sit thee down and write
In a book that all may read__
So he vanish'd from my sight.
And I pluck'd a hollow reed.
And I made a rural pen,
And I stain'd the water clear,
And I wrote my happy songs,
Every child may joy to hear

desc.objtitle:
The Ecchoing Green The Echoing Green,
Object 4 (Bentley 6, Erdman 6, Keynes 6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A group of four adults—the text mentions "old folk" (Object 4, line 16) and "mothers" (Object 5, line 12)—including two adults on the left, both wearing brimmed hats, and two females wearing a scarf over her head (center) or a cap (right) sit presumably on a circular bench at the base of the trunk of a large oak tree. They superintend five young children who stand at their knees or sit in their laps. Behind them five older children play and stroll on a grassy area. The dense, umbrella-shaped canopy of the central tree spreads over the entire scene. Other trees or bushes fill the background, and a patch of blue sky peeks through the foliage at right. The shadows along the lower edge of the design suggest that the time is late afternoon or early evening ("the darkening Green" of line 17 on the following Object).

component.illusobjdesc: On the left end of a bench at the base of the central tree sit two adults. The adult furthest left may have long hair and be among the "old folk" (line 16). She(?) is gowned and wears a brimmed hat. Her left arm is at her side and also rests in her lap. She appears to be looking down at the child who stands by her knees.

On the left end of a bench at the base of the central tree sit two adults. The second adult from the left, hands on his knees, left leg forward, stares directly ahead to the left margin with wide eyes. He wears a brimmed hat and knee breeches. Long-haired, he may be among the "old folk"(line 16).
A small child with short, curly hair stands at the knees of the first adult sitting on the left side of the tree trunk and looks up at him or her.

Two females in full gowns—nurses or the "mothers" (Object 5, line 12) mentioned in the text—sit on a bench at the base of a large oak tree. There are two children standing in front of the woman in the center, one at each knee. Her right arm rests on the back of, and perhaps holds, the child at the left. She wears a scarf over her head and faces forward, but with her head twisted to the right.
Two children stand at the knees of a woman seated directly in front of an oak tree. The child on the left, in a gown, lays its head in her lap, face toward the viewer, and may be sleeping.

Two children stand at the knees of a woman seated directly in front of an oak tree. The child on the right, short-haired, clothed in tights(?) and probably male, reaches up with his right hand and rests his left on her knee. He is facing away from the viewer.

Two females in full gowns—nurses or the "mothers" (Object 5, line 12) mentioned in the text—sit on a bench at the base of a large oak tree. A child stands at the knees of a woman on the right, and she holds an infant in her lap while cradling it with her arms. She looks down at the children and may be wearing a cap.
A child, wearing a gown, stands at the knees of a woman seated on the right side of the group under the oak tree. He or she looks away to the right.
The woman seated on the right side of the group under the oak tree holds a curly-haired and possibly nude infant or very young child in her lap. The child's left arm appears to be bent at the elbow.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. Left of the tree trunk two male children wearing breeches play an unidentified ball game(?). The child at far left, who may wear a semi-transparent shirt and faces away from the viewer, stands with his legs spread, his right arm at his side, and holding a bat with his raised left hand. A ball is pictured between his head and the bat.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. Left of the tree trunk two male children wearing breeches play an unidentified ball game(?). The short-haired child second from left, who faces the viewer, stands with his legs spread, his arms raised horizontally and palms up or facing the viewer. He may be nude from the waist up.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. At far right two children—the nearest one dressed as a male—walk together, facing left. The front-most youth has curly hair and holds his bent left arm at his side.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. At far right two children walk together, facing left. The features of the child back and furthest right are indistinct. The figure may have long hair and wear tights.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. To the right of the tree trunk stands a short-haired(?) child, arms at his(?) side, who may be playing a ball game with the two standing children to the left of the trunk. He may be wearing tights and a shirt.

The thick-leaved, umbrella-shaped canopy of the central tree spreads over the entire scene. Other trees or bushes fill the background. The lower reaches of this background vegetation may form a hedge.
The child at the far left holds a bat in his upraised left hand. A ball appears between the bat and his head.
The dark shadows just above the lower margin of the image suggest that the time is late afternoon or early evening ("the darkening Green" of line 17 on the following Object).
A large grassy area—the "darkening Green" of line 17 on the following Object—spreads beneath and behind the central oak tree.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the left, dressed in a shirt and breeches, stands erect, holding a bat by his side with his right hand while his left hand is hidden behind him. The one on the right, also dressed in a shirt and knee breeches, runs behind a large hoop that he rolls with a stick in his right hand. Leafy grapevines, possibly rooted at the bottom of the plate, flourish to the left and right of the text, and the space between the stanzas is filled with a tendril from the vine on the right, which also bears a cluster of grapes to the right of the second stanza. The title of the poem is decorated with lively vegetation. A vine sprouts from the initial "T" in the title and the final "n" sends out buds and blossoms that surround the head of the boy beneath. A bird with outspread wings and forked tail flies to the right of the grapes. A light blue wash around the text suggests sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the left, short-haired, dressed in a shirt and breeches, stands erect in contrapposto, holding a bat by his side with his right hand while his left hand is hidden behind him.
Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the right, short-haired, dressed in a shirt and knee breeches, runs behind a large hoop that he rolls with a stick in his right hand.

Leafy grapevines, rooted at the bottom of the plate, flourish to the left and right of the text, and the space between the stanzas is filled with a loopy tendril from the vine on the right, which also bears a cluster of grapes to the right of the second stanza. The title of the poem is decorated with lively vegetation. A vine sprouts from the initial "T" in the title and the final "n" sends out buds and blossoms that surround the head of the boy beneath.
The boy on the left holds a bat by his side.
A bird with outspread wings and forked tail flies to the right of the grapes.
A light blue wash around the text suggests sky. Pink washes to the left of the text suggest sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: The Sun does arise,
And make happy the skies
The merry bells ring
To welcome the Spring.
The sky-lark and thrush,
The birds of the bush,
Sing louder around,
To the bells chearful sound.
While our sports shall be seen
On the Ecchoing Green.
Old John with white hair
Does laugh away care
Sitting under the oak,
Among the old folk

l.note: "They" is printed very faintly in this copy.

desc.objtitle:
The Ecchoing Green (continued) The echoing Green (continued),
Object 5 (Bentley 7, Erdman 7, Keynes 7)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a background colored to suggest twilight on the "darkening Green" (line 17), a procession of nine adults and children (including one infant) in a variety of positions moves generally leftward. Overhead in the branches of two intertwining grape vines that are rooted at lower right and grow upward along the right margin and left to embrace the stanzas of the poem, one boy, left, stretches on tiptoe to reach a cluster of grapes on the left while a second boy, right, hands another cluster to a girl who reaches up from the grass below. Next to her, walking left, is a long-haired male in hat and tights; he holds a bunch of grapes in his extended left hand. Next in line is a woman who looks down at the infant in her arms. A small child stands just to the left. In the center, the tallest figure in the group, perhaps "Old John with white hair" (line 12, Object 4), points forward with his right hand. A boy to the left, who faces away from the viewer, holds a bat at his side with his left hand. At the front of the procession are a boy and girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. Between them is a kite that the girl may be holding. The green tinting of the ground below the playful procession suggests grass.

component.illusobjdesc: Standing on a branch of a luxuriant grapevine, a short-haired, nude boy with his head bent back, seen in profile, stretches on tiptoe to reach a cluster of grapes with his upraised right arm. His mouth appears to be open.

Lying on a branch of a luxuriant grape vine, a curly-haired boy in tights hands a cluster of grapes down to a girl on the grass below. He may be holding the vine with his left hand. His right leg is bent at the knee. His body faces forward with his head turned part-way to the left.

A girl in a full gown and a hat that resembles a halo reaches up with her left hand to take a cluster of grapes from a boy lying on the grapevine above her. At least her left foot is on tiptoe. She looks up toward the grapes.

Walking left among the lower group of figures, second from right, is a long-haired youthful male in brimmed hat and tights. He holds a bunch of grapes in his extended left hand. His left foot is forward.
Among the lower group of figures, third from the right, stands (or walks) a woman in a full gown who looks down at the infant in her arms. She faces left. Her hair seems to be pulled back in a bun.

Among the lower group of figures, fourth from the right and crowded between two larger adults, stands or walks a small boy in tights who faces forward but looks up toward the woman and infant to the right.
There is an infant in the arms of the woman third from the right among the lower group of figures.

In the center of the lower group of figures, the tallest figure, with long hair, brimmed hat, and dressed in coat and knee breeches—perhaps "Old John with white hair"—walks to the left and points in that direction with his right hand. His left arm is at his side, but may be reaching down to the boy holding a bat.
Among the lower group of figures, third from the left, facing away from the viewer, stands (in a contrapposto posture) or walks a curly-haired boy in tights who holds a bat in his extended left hand.

At the front of the procession of figures are a boy, with curly hair and wearing tights, and a girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. His arms are at his side, and he stands in a contrapposto stance. His head and shoulders are silhouetted against the kite behind him.
At the front of the procession of figures are a boy and girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. Between them is a kite that she may be holding. She is long-haired and wears a gown.

A luxuriant grapevine, or rather two vines intertwined, are rooted at lower right and grow upward along the right margin. One vine continues up the right margin, while the other branches left to embrace the stanzas of the poem. There are leaves here and there on the vines, a grape cluster at the upper left, over the head of a boy who stretches to pick them, a second cluster beside the head of the boy in the branches on the right, and a third in his hand. There is also a bunch of grapes in the extended left hand of the boy walking to the left, second figure from the right. Green tinting on the ground below the parade of figures suggests grass.
There are two children's toys in the lower procession of figures: a kite between the boy and girl on the left, and a bat held by the boy to the right of them.
The area behind the lower procession of figures is colored to suggest sky at sunset—the "darkening Green" (line 17) of the text.

lg.l: They laugh at our play,
And soon they all say.
Such such were the joys.
When we all girls & boys,
In our youth-time were seen,
On the Ecchoing Green
Till the little ones weary
No more can be merry
The sun does descend,
And our sports have an end.
Round the laps of their mothers
Many sisters and brothers,
Like birds in their nest.
Are ready for rest:
And sport no more seenThe final letter of "seen" is weakly printed.
On the darkening Green.

desc.objtitle:
The Blossom,
Object 6 (Bentley 11, Erdman 11, Keynes 11)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Originating at lower right, an extravagant plant formed of giant, flame-like leaves surrounds the poem on three sides. In its upper reaches there is a circle of eight figures (clockwise from the far right): (1) a nude infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically; (2) a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, sitting on part of the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title; (3) she seems to be holding an infant in her arms; (4) to her left, a nude winged figure, kneeling or sitting, facing left and probably reading a book or tablet below the figure's left hand; (5 and 6) far left, two winged figures who fly facing one another (one facing away from, and the other facing toward, the viewer); (7 and 8) and a second pair of winged nude figures, kneeling and facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). All the figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central lower pair (2 and 3 above) may be the female blossom who addresses the sparrow and robin in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures: at far right is a forward-facing nude infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically, its left foot forward.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures: in the center, a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, sits on part of the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title. Her right leg appears to be crossed below her left leg; her left leg and foot extend downward and to the right. She may be holding an infant in her arms. The figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, this pair may be the female blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures: in the center, a winged female(?) sitting on the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" may be holding an infant in her arms. The figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. In that case the infant may represent one of those birds.

The human figures in the plant probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central winged female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. In that case the infant(?) may represent one of those birds.

The human figures in the plant probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central winged female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. Above the "B" of "Blossom" in the title is a winged figure, nude(?), kneeling or sitting, facing left and perhaps reading in the book or tablet to which the figure points with his left arm (raised at about 45 degrees) and hand.
The small winged figure above the "B" of "Blossom" in the title points towards a book or tablet immediately to the left of this figure.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At far left are two nude winged figures who fly facing one another. The one who faces away from the viewer is perhaps male(?). His arms are raised horizontally, and his legs are spread.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At far left are two nude winged figures who fly facing one another. The one who faces forward is probably another nude putto, but might be female. Its arms are raised at 45 degrees, both to the right, and its legs are together, left forward.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At top center is a second pair of winged nude figures, kneeling and facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). One leg of the figure on the left is extended backward.
Originating at lower right, an extravagant plant formed of giant, flame-like leaves surrounds the poem on three sides.
Yellow background washes suggest a sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Merry Merry Sparrow
Under leaves so green
A happy Blossom
Sees you swift as arrow
Seek your cradle narrow
Near my Bosom.
Pretty Pretty Robin
Under leaves so green
A happy Blossom
Hears you sobbing sobbing
Pretty Pretty Robin
Near my Bosom.

desc.objtitle:
Spring,
Object 7 (Bentley 22, Erdman 22, Keynes 22)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Sitting beneath the branches of a tree with its trunk behind her, a gowned woman with hair pulled back (and held with a ribbon or string?) looks out toward a flock of grazing sheep. She holds a nude infant—perhaps her own—who stands in her lap and gestures with upraised arms toward the sheep. Low hills define the horizon above the sheep. The slight pink and yellow coloring of the sky above the hills indicates a sunrise or sunset. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem.

component.illusobjdesc: Sitting to the right of a large tree trunk, a gowned woman with hair pulled back into a bun (held with a ribbon or string?) looks out toward a flock of grazing sheep. She holds a nude(?) infant—perhaps her own—who stands in her lap. Her right foot is visible beneath the hem of her gown.

A seated woman holds her(?) short-haired nude(?) infant, who stands in her lap and gestures with upraised arms toward the sheep. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem.

A mother and her(?) infant overlook a flock of grazing sheep. In the final stanza of the poem, an infant or child speaks to a "Little Lamb," and this may be the animal with head raised to the right of the woman's left knee.
The horizon above the sheep is defined by low hills. Above, the yellow and pink coloring of the sky indicates a sunrise or sunset.
The leaves of a tree, its trunk just right of the left margin, extend over the woman and infant. The dark coloring on the trunk lower left might indicate a shadow.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the decorative vegetation seems to originate in and around the title lettering. A vine curls left of the "S" of "Spring" and dangles (with loops and leaves) down the left margin of the text. Another cluster of vegetation bursts from the side of the "g" of "Spring"; curls back over the title; expands downward into the large spaces of the right margin with long, thin leaves, a loopy tendril, and several tassels of grain. Another vine curves around the end of long line 11 and expands into the space left by the remaining short lines on the plate, ending in two tassels of grain. Two winged angels occupy this vegetation, one seated, facing right, and playing a pipe right of lines 3-4; the other reclining on one arm right of line 12. Blue background washes indicate sky, and faint pink and yellow washes near the bottom of the plate suggests sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Two winged angels with obscure features occupy the vegetation to the right of the text: one seated, facing right, and playing a pipe opposite lines 3-4; the other, wings outspread, reclining on one arm opposite line 12.

Most of the decorative vegetation seems to originate in and around the title lettering. A vine curls left of the "S" of "Spring" and dangles (with loops and leaves) down the left margin of the text. Another cluster of vegetation bursts from the side of the "g" of "Spring"; curls back over the title; expands downward into the large spaces of the right margin with long, thin leaves, a loopy tendril, and several tassels of grain. Another vine curves around the end of long line 11 and expands into the space left by the remaining short lines on the plate. This vine ends in two tassels of grain.
Blue background washes indicate sky, and faint pink and yellow washes near the bottom of the plate suggest sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Sound the Flute!
Now it's mute
Birds delight
Day and Night.
Nightingale
In the dale
Lark in Sky
Merrily (Year
Merrily Merrily to welcome in the
Little Boy
Full of joy.

desc.objtitle:
Spring (continued),
Object 8 (Bentley 23, Erdman 23, Keynes 23)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude child with curly hair reclines on grassy ground. With both hands the child touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. Two sheep also lie on the ground, left and right of the child. He or she may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem. Blue background washes suggest sky.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude young child, probably male, with short, curly hair reclines, with left leg crossed over extended right leg, in the midst of a group of three sheep. With his left hand the child touches the neck—and with his right hand the back—of a lamb to the left; the two of them look at one another. The child may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem. There are slight suggestions of male genitals.

An infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. Grown sheep lie on the right and left; the one on the right faces forward while the one on the left appears to be watching the lamb and infant.
The green wash on the ground beneath the infant and sheep suggests grass.
Blue background washes indicate sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom. Two grain tassels grow from this framing vine; the lower tassel dangles through the right side of the vignette. Two clusters of similar vegetation, each with at least one grain tassel, fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. There is a figure associated with each cluster of vegetation in the right margin: below, a gowned angel with large wings sitting on a curve of the plant with her(?) knees drawn up and her head down; above, a gowned figure standing, with arms outspread, in a semi-circle made by the plant. blue and pink background washes suggest the sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Right of the first stanza, a gowned figure stands in a semi-circle made by a vine or leaf. Her(?) arms are outspread, partially hidden by the vine-like plant that circles around in front of her. Her body may be twisting away from the viewer, and she may be pointing upward.
Right of the last stanza, a winged, gowned angel sits on a curve of the plant with her(?) legs drawn up and her head down, her body facing left.

Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom. Two clusters of similar vegetation fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. There are grain tassels at the right side of the lower vignette, to the right of lines 14-16, below the last few words in line 8, and just below the top right corner of the plate.
Blue and pink background washes suggest sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Little Girl
Sweet and small
Cock does crow
So do you
Merry voice
Infant noise
Merrily Merrily to welcome in the Year
Little Lamb
Here I am.
Come and lick
My white neck.
Let me pull
Your soft Wool.
Let me kiss
Your soft face. Year
Merrily Merrily we welcome in the

desc.objtitle:
Infant Joy,
Object 9 (Bentley 25, Erdman 25, Keynes 25)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding an infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged female angel wearing a transparent gown who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. Each of her small wings is marked with a dot. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 7). A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the center-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one. Blue background washes suggest sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding a nude infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. She may be smiling. To the right, facing them, stands a winged female angel wearing a transparent gown who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 7).

Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a drooping closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the middle-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one.
Blue background washes indicate sky.

lg.l: I have no name
I am but two days old.__
What shall I call thee?
I happy am
Joy is my name,__
Sweet joy befall thee!
Pretty joy!
Sweet joy but two days old,
Sweet joy I call thee;
Thou dost smile.
I sing the while
Sweet joy befall thee.

desc.objtitle:
The Voice of the Ancient Bard,
Object 10 (Bentley 54, Erdman 54, Keynes 54)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned, bearded old man stands, playing a large harp, before an audience of perhaps two children—standing in the middle of the group—and six older youths. He may be the bard of the title. To the left stand two young females who embrace. To the right stand the two children and a group of three gowned females who face the bard. At their feet, facing them, kneels another female. All the figures appear to be gowned. The scene is set outdoors on a strip of slightly inclined grassy ground with a dark shadow lower right. A palm-like frond arches over the head of the figure at far right and the vine in the left margin of the text dangles down into this major design above the heads of the embracing couple. Blue wash indicates sky, with rose and yellow coloring suggesting sunrise and sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At left stands an embracing couple. The young female, with curly hair, faces away from the viewer with her right arm raised vertically to embrace the neck of her companion. Her left arm may rest on her companion's right shoulder.

At left stands an embracing couple. Facing left, the taller figure might be an older female. Her hair is short or drawn back into a bun. She looks down at the other figure and holds her visible hand on her companion's buttocks.

A tall, bearded old man in a gown stands facing right as he plays a large triangular harp with a bent right arm and a raised left one. He may be the bard of the title. His right foot shows beneath the hem of his garment.

In the middle of the group, just right of the old man, stand two gowned children (distinctly shorter than their companions). The listening child to the left faces forward and looks up toward the bard or his harp. The child on the right faces right as he looks up toward the threesome to the right.

At right stand three young gowned females, at least the one on the left with short hair. They look toward and listen to the bard. The left-most of the three holds her arm, slightly bent, at her side; the right-most faces left and bends her arm up to hold the arm of the middle figure. At their feet and facing away from the viewer kneels a fourth young female similarly dressed and coiffured. She looks toward the threesome rather than at the bard. Her left arm is bent upward, with her left hand raised and fingers spread apart.
Over the head of the figure at far right arches a palm-like frond.
The green tinting of the ground beneath the figures' feet suggests grass.

Blue tinting indicates sky, with rose and yellow coloring suggesting sunrise or sunset. A dark shadow extends from the lower right corner, and another appears between the kneeling figure and the base of the bard's harp.
An old man, perhaps a bard, plays a large triangular harp that rests on the ground at his feet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title is a large, spiky leaf (uncolored in this copy). A vine right of lines 4-11 branches into three leaves on three long stems, with the rightmost leaf and stem detached from the other two. A vine descends in the left margin of the text and into the sky of the lower design.

component.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title is a large, spiky leaf (uncolored in this copy). A vine right of lines 4-11 branches into three leaves on three long stems, with the rightmost leaf and stem detached from the other two. A vine descends in the left margin of the text and into the sky of the lower design.

lg.l: Youth of delight come hither
And see the opening morn,
Image of truth new-born
Doubt is fled & clouds of reason.
Dark disputes & artful teazing.
Folly is an endless maze,
Tangled roots perplex her ways,
How many have fallen there!
They stumble all night over bones of the dead:
And feel they know not what but care;
And wish to lead others when they should be led

desc.objtitle:
The Shepherd,
Object 11 (Bentley 5, Erdman 5, Keynes 5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young, curly-haired male shepherd in tights stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep. He holds a crook in his left hand; his shepherd's purse, or wallet, is visible near his right knee. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks forward and beside it another sheep lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree, and a plant with lily-like blossoms grows up beside its base. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees and a hilltop in the background, where pink and yellow washes suggest that the time is sunrise or sunset. On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends. Three smaller birds soar to the right of the large bird. At least one other bird, perhaps two, perches on the section of the branch below and to the right of the three flying birds.

component.illusobjdesc: A young male shepherd with short, curly hair wears tights and stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep—perhaps looking at the sheep that lifts its head toward him. He holds a crook in his left hand; his purse is visible near his right knee. His arms are bent at the elbow, with his body facing forward but his head turned to the left.

A shepherd watches his grazing flock of sheep. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks straight ahead and beside it another sheep—possibly one of the "lambs" of line 7—lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. Two, perhaps three, sheep in the middle of the flock have raised heads and look right, but most appear to have their heads lowered to the ground, including the ram and several others in front.

Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree, and a plant with lily-like blossoms grows up beside its base. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees in the background.
The coloring of the ground indicates grass.
Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree, and plant with lily-like blossoms grows up beside its base.

There are more trees and a hilltop in the background. A shadow covers the lower portion of this vegetation, just over the sheep, and possibly under the sheep between their legs. A triangular shadow extends from the bottom right corner of the design.
Blue tinting indicates the sky. Pink and yellow washes behind and below the poem's text suggest sunrise or sunset.

On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends in the sky. Three much smaller birds soar to the right of the large one. At least one other bird, perhaps two, perches on the section of the branch below and to the right of the three flying birds.
The shepherd's purse is visible beside his right knee.
The shepherd holds a crook.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with leaves branches off the "T" in "The" in the title.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with leaves branches off the "T" in "The" in the title.

lg.l: How sweet is the Shepherds sweet lot!
From the morn to the evening he strays:
He shall follow his sheep all the day
And his tongue shall be filled with praise.
For he hears the lambs innocent call.
And he hears the ewes tender reply.
He is watchful while they are in peace.
For they know when their Shepherd is nigh.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Black Boy,
Object 12 (Bentley 9, Erdman 9, Keynes 9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At dawn, an adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child who points upward with his left hand. With her right hand she reaches across her lap toward the boy. Presumably they correspond to the "mother" (lines 3, 7) and "Little Black Boy" (title) of the text. They are both dark of skin. The pair sits under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother. A vine twines upward around the tree trunk on the left in a counter-clockwise direction. A second tree, with fewer leaves and much smaller, grows up the right margin and arches over the sun. A hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon. "The rising sun" of the text (line 11) mounts above the horizon in a yellow and rosy sky. Dark shadows extend below the figures and to the right along the ground and behind the female.

component.illusobjdesc: Under a tree, a long-haired, dark-skinned adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child. With her right hand she reaches across her lap toward the boy and points toward the right. Presumably she corresponds to the "mother" (lines 3, 7) of the text.

Under a tree, an adult female sits facing a kneeling(?) child, apparently nude and male with short hair, who points upward with his left hand. Presumably he is the "Little Black Boy" of the text. They are both dark of skin.
The mother and child sit under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother.
A vine twines upward around the tree trunk on the left in a counter-clockwise direction.
"The rising sun" of the text (line 11) mounts above the horizon in a yellow and rosy sky.
A second tree, with fewer leaves and much smaller than the one on the left, grows up the right margin and arches over the rising sun.
A hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon. Dark shadows extend below the figures and on the ground to the right and behind the female.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the bottom left, a pair of intertwined vines grows up the left margin and around the words of the title. From the same point at lower left, a third vine, thin with many loops, crosses beneath the last stanza on the plate just above the lower margin, then continues up the right margin, filling up spaces left by the text and terminating just below line 13 of the text. Another vine with loops and leaves fills the right margin above. The capital "T" and "L" of the title are ornamented to harmonize with the vines, and there is an elaborate bit of detached vegetation between and above "Little" and "Black." A single bird with outspread wings flies in the margin to the right of line 7, after "tree." Blue and pink background washes suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the bottom left, a pair of intertwined vines grows up the left margin and around the words of the title. From the same point at lower left, a third vine, thin with many loops, crosses beneath the last stanza on the plate just above its bottom margin, then continues up the right margin, filling up spaces left by the text and terminating just below the end of line 13. One extension of this vine descends in a spiral in the plate's lower right corner. Above, another vine with loops and leaves fills the remaining spaces right of the text. The capital "T" and "L" of the title are ornamented to harmonize with the vines, and there is an elaborate bit of detached vegetation between and above "Little" and "Black."
A single bird with outspread wings flies in the margin to the right of line 7, after "tree."
Blue and pink background washes suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: My mother bore me in the southern wild,
And I am black, but O! my soul is white
White as an angel is the English child:
But I am black as if bereav'd of light.
My mother taught me underneath a tree
And sitting down before the heat of day.
She took me on her lap and kissed me,
And pointing to the east began to say.
Look on the rising sun! there God does live
And gives his light. and gives his heat away.
And flowers and trees and beasts and men recieve
Comfort in morning. joy in the noon day.
And we are put on earth a little space.
That we may learn to bear the beams of love,
And these black bodies and this sun-burnt face
Is but a cloud, and like a shady grove.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 13 (Bentley 10, Erdman 10, Keynes 10)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The elements of the design combine and develop a selection of those on the previous Object. Christ, in conventional representation as a shepherd with beard, gown, and crook, sits facing left on a bank. Two nude boys—one blue-gray and one white in this copy—stand in front of him. One, probably the "little English boy" (line 7) whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem, stands at Jesus's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Jesus, who looks down at him. The other boy, probably the little black boy from the previous Object though not as dark-skinned as he was there (presumably in conformation with the sense of "When I from black and he from white cloud free," line 8), stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 12). All three are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads. A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy. Wavy lines and blue-gray coloring suggest a river running at the foot of the plate. A vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ, in conventional representation as a shepherd with long hair, beard, gown, and crook, sits facing left on a bank with two children standing in front of him. Holding his crook between his legs and across his left shoulder, he rests his left arm on his lap with his hand on his knee. His left foot is exposed.

To the left of the English boy and Christ, a second nude child with short, curly hair, probably the little black boy from the previous Object though now not as dark-skinned (presumably in conformation with the sense of "When I from black and he from white cloud free," line 8), stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 12).

The nude and curly-haired "little English boy" whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem stands at Christ's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Christ, who looks down at him. The boy's right leg is extended backward.
A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy.
A few low hills fill the horizon above the sheep.
Rose tinting in the sky suggests a sunrise or sunset.
All three of the figures are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads.
A double vine (the smaller, on the left, very short in this copy) rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin. Both stems bear leaves or flowers.
Jesus sits on a bank in which a tree and double vine are rooted.
Wavy lines and blue-gray coloring may indicate a river running across the foot of the plate.
In a sitting position, Christ holds a shepherd's crook between his legs and across his left shoulder.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A flowering(?) vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar but detached vegetation completes the circuit around the top and down the left side of the text. The vine in the left margin is intertwined with another vine.

component.illusobjdesc: A flowering(?) vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar but detached vegetation completes the circuit around the top and down the left side of the text. The vine in the left margin is intertwined with another vine.

lg.l: For when our souls have learn'd the heat to bear
The cloud will vanish we shall hear his voice.
Saying: come out from the grove my love & care,
And round my golden tent like lambs rejoice.
Thus did my mother say and kissed me.
And thus I say to little English boy.
When I from black and he from white cloud free,
And round the tent of God like lambs we joy:
Ill shade him from the heat till he can bear,
To lean in joy upon our fathers knee.
And then I'll stand and stroke his silver hair.
And be like him and he will then love me.

desc.objtitle:
On Anothers Sorrow On Another's Sorrow,
Object 14 (Bentley 27, Erdman 27, Keynes 27)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right edge of the plate. A vine grows up around its trunk; grape clusters(?) are visible opposite stanzas 6 and 7. At the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near the bird with long tail feathers that ascends to the right of stanza 6. Other birds fly to the right of lines 7 and 13. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable. The left margin is dominated by a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree. A figure playing a pipe stands next to the right tree, lower left. There is a second figure climbing in the branches above, left of stanzas 7 and 8. A third human form, left of stanza 1, stands facing right with both arms raised. Blue, yellow, and pink washes around the designs suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: There are three figures in the left margin. A figure, facing left, stands at the base of the tree on the left and plays a pipe. A second figure climbs in the branches left of stanzas 7 and 8. The final figure, clearly represented left of stanza 1, stands facing right with both arms raised vertically; this figure appears to be gowned.
A bird with long tail feathers ascends to the right of stanza 6. Two other birds fly to the right of lines 7 and 13.

A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right margin. A vine grows up its trunk; at the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near stanza 6. The vine bears grape clusters opposite stanzas 6 and 7. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable. In the left margin is a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree.
The standing figure at bottom left is playing a pipe.
Blue, yellow, and pink washes around the designs suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Can I see anothers woe,
And not be in sorrow too.
Can I see anothers grief.
And not seek for kind relief.
Can I see a falling tear.
And not feel my sorrows share,
Can a father see his child,
Weep, nor be with sorrow fill'd.
Can a mother sit and hear.
An infant groan an infant fear__
No no never can it be.
Never never can it be.
And can he who smiles on all
Hear the wren with sorrows small.
Hear the small birds grief & care
Hear the woes that infants bear__
And not sit beside the nest
Pouring pity in their breast.
And not sit the cradle near
Weeping tear on infants tear.
And not sit both night & day.
Wiping all our tears away.
O! no never can it be.
Never never can it be.
He doth give his joy to all,
He becomes an infant small.
He becomes a man of woe
He doth feel the sorrow too.
Think not, thou canst sigh a sigh,
And thy maker is not by.
Think not, thou canst weep a tear,
And thy maker is not near.
O! he gives to us his joy.
That our grief he may destroy
Till our grief is fled & gone
He doth sit by us and moan

desc.objtitle:
A CRADLE SONG,
Object 15 (Bentley 16, Erdman 16, Keynes 16)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Indeterminate (but varied) vegetation interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. There are at least three figures in the letters "A," "C," and "D" of the title; six(?) in the left margin; and five(?) in the right.

component.illusobjdesc: There are at least three figures in the letters of the title: a piper playing(?) as he leans against the left side of the "A"; a figure sitting inside the "C"; and a figure standing inside the "D." There may be a small child or infant, facing left, in the lap of the figure in the "C." Alternatively this may simply be the larger figure's left arm bent upward.
A piper plays his pipe(?) as he leans against the letter "A" in the title.

There are six(?) figures in the left margin (top to bottom): a figure standing with her(?) arm raised vertically beside the second stanza; a small figure next to "Hover" (line 12) who may be dancing or simply hovering, and just beneath it a sitting figure, who may hold a child or infant in her lap; a seated, gowned, hunched over figure, with head lowered and at least one arm on its lap, left of the fifth stanza; and, beside the sixth stanza, a standing figure with head up and arm raised, possibly to grasp the vegetation overhead.

There are five(?) figures visible in the right margin (top to bottom): a gowned figure seated, with head down, right of line 5; a gowned female(?) figure lying horizontally, arm extended, in the flame-like vegetation to the right of lines 6 and 7; a figure standing with arms raised and legs spread, perhaps dancing, in the vegetation to the right of line 11; a figure seated on one of the vines, with one leg bent and the other extended downward, at the right of line 16; and a figure walking right at the end of lines 17-18.

Indeterminate vegetation of various sorts interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. The dominant form is perhaps the vegetation with flame-like leaves that swirls in the spaces of the right margin (with a more conventional leaf or two at bottom right), underneath the title, and down the left margin. Tendrils extending from both margins help separate the stanzas from one another. The vine right of the final stanza on the plate has several loops suggesting a spiral. The vine full of leaves and flowers(?) that extends across the top of the plate above the title and fills the top right corner and the space right of the first stanza is distinct from the flame-like vegetation that dominates the rest of the plate. Extensions of letters in the title contribute to both forms of vegetation: the initial "A" and "C" to the vine above, the "S" to both. In the text of the poem, occasional letters have modest decorative extensions, and there are a few bits of stray decorative vegetation.
Blue background washes surrounding the text indicate sky.

lg.l: Sweet dreams form a shade,
O'er my lovely infants head,
Sweet dreams of pleasant streams,
By happy silent moony beams
Sweet sleep with soft down.
Weave thy brows an infant crown.
Sweet sleep Angel mild,
Hover o'er my happy child.
Sweet smiles in the night,
Hover over my delight.
Sweet smiles Mothers smiles
All the livelong night beguiles.
Sweet moans. dovelike sighs.
Chase not slumber from thy eyes,
Sweet moans. sweeter smiles.
All the dovelike moans beguiles.
Sleep sleep happy child.
All creation slept and smil'd.
Sleep sleep. happy sleep.
While o'er thee thy mother weep
Sweet babe in thy face.
Holy image I can trace.
Sweet babe once like thee.
Thy maker lay and wept for me

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 16 (Bentley 17, Erdman 17, Keynes 17)

illustration.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother dressed in a high-waisted gown and hat or headdress of some sort leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a hooded wicker cradle. The infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the infant with Christ: "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 8). A dark shadow covers the floor below the woman. Fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background.

component.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother, dressed in a high-waisted gown and hat, scarf, or headdress of some sort, leans over an infant in a cradle. She faces right; at least her right arm, and probably her left, are folded in front of her.

A nurse or mother leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a cradle. The configuration of the infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the smiling infant with Christ: "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 8).
The configuration of the infant's pillow suggests a halo.
An infant sleeps in a wicker cradle with a hood that arches over the infant's head.
A dark shadow falls over the floor beneath the cradle, chair, and on the far left over both the floor and the background curtain.
Fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background.
The mother or nurse sits in a curved-back chair.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous object reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 6) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the left margin and beneath the text. In the left margin there are four human figures: beside the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands with an infant(?) in her arms; left of lines 6-7 is a running or leaping figure with arms raised horizontally; and left of line 8 is a small gowned figure facing, and perhaps walking, left.

component.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous object reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 6) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the right margin and beneath the text. Two of these are extensions of letters in the text: the "S" of "Smiles" (line 6) and the "p" of "peace" (line 9).
Left of the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands, facing right, with an infant(?) in her arms.
Left of lines 6-7, a small figure strides or leaps or hovers in the air, facing right. Its legs are spread apart and its arms raised horizontally.
A tiny figure, perhaps gowned, hovers or walks to the left just left of line 8. This may be the "Infant" referenced in the first word of line 8.

lg.l: Wept for me for thee for all
When he was an infant small.
Thou his image ever see.
Heavenly face that smiles on thee.
Smiles on thee on me on all.
Who became an infant small,
Infant smiles are his own smiles,
Heaven & earth to peace beguiles

desc.objtitle:
The Divine Image,
Object 17 (Bentley 18, Erdman 18, Keynes 18)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A serpentine plant-like structure with flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at right in the strip of grassy ground that runs across the bottom of the plate, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward flourish at top left. The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a leafy vine that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin right of the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant, which the vine continues to climb, finally terminating just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure. There are several human figures on and around the plants: (at top left) a nude female with long hair walks right, trailing a flowing blue cloth; a second female, gowned and with long hair, floats behind her, pointing right; two figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer; (at bottom right) a gowned figure stands, with an arm extended, perhaps touching the left hand of a nude male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically; below and in front of this pair, a third figure, perhaps female and gowned, reclines, supported on her left arm. Blue background washes indicate sky, with suggestions of pink clouds at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At top left, a nude woman with long hair walks right, trailing a flowing blue cloth. She may carry a vase or pitcher in her left hand, which is by her side, and another indistinguishable object beneath her right arm. A gowned female with long hair hovers behind her, turning her head to look back at the first woman, and points right.
The nude woman walking at top left may carry a vase or pitcher in her left hand.
Two gowned figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer.

At bottom right, a figure in a high-waisted gown stands, with left arm extended, perhaps touching the left hand of a nude short-haired male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically toward the hand of the standing figure. Below and in front of the male pair, a third figure, probably female and gowned, reclines, supported on her left arm. The male and female conceivably represent Adam and Eve; the standing gowned figure may be Christ.

A serpentine plant-like structure with flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at bottom right, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward curl at top left.

The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a leafy vine that appears to originate, like the plant itself, from the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin behind the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant (sending out occasional tendrils to the left, into the spaces left by short lines of the poem) until it terminates in a cluster of leaves that dangles just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure.
The flame-like plant and vine are apparently rooted at bottom right in the strip of grassy ground that runs across the bottom of the plate.
Blue background washes indicate sky, with suggestions of pink clouds at sunrise or sunset.
The dark area lower right, right of the standing figure, might be a shadow.

lg.l: To Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
All pray in their distress:
And to these virtues of delight
Return their thankfulness.
For Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
Is God our father dear:
And Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
Is Man his child and care.
For Mercy has a human heart
Pity, a human face:
And Love, the human form divine.
And Peace, the human dress.
Then every man of every clime,
That prays in his distress,
Prays to the human form divine
Love Mercy Pity Peace.
And all must love the human form.
In heathen, turk or jew,
Where Mercy, Love & Pity dwell,
There God is dwelling too.

desc.objtitle:
HOLY THURSDAY,
Object 18 (Bentley 19, Erdman 19, Keynes 19)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some may hold one another around the waist or shoulder. They all wear hats. They are led by a pair of gowned adults, both with hats, one carrying a staff or scepter. At the bottom of the plate a similar procession occurs, though with seven pairs of girls instead of nine of boys, walking left instead of right, and led by a single gowned female(?) figure. The girls wear dresses. The male and female figures altogether represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 3-7).

component.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats and hats walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some hold one another around the waist or shoulder. Along with the figures at the bottom, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" (lines 3-6).

The procession of children is led by a pair of robed adults, probably male(?), both with hats, one holding a staff or scepter. They are the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" (line 6).
A beadle at the head of the procession holds a staff or scepter, one of the "wands" (line 6) of the text.
Blue washes above the procession of boys indicate sky.

Seven pairs of girls walk left, led by a single adult figure. The girls wear uniform dresses. Their positions are not always clear; girls in the fourth and fifth pairs from the right gesture with their hands. Along with the figures at the top, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 3-7).
The procession of girls is led by a single adult and gowned figure, probably female, facing left and perhaps walking.
The robed figure who is leading the procession may be wearing a cap or wig and may be holding something (in other copies more clearly a book).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is crowded with a mixture of interlinear vegetation, animals, birds, and human figures. The block letters of the title are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S" and "Y" of "THURSDAY") and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird (below "into the" in line 7) or human figure (beneath "innocent" in line 11). Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves but including a bird hovering on a vine, wings outspread, facing the viewer. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "seated" in line 8 and above "their" in line 11) or human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY") but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

component.illusobjdesc: There is a tiny human figure, running with arms raised horizontally, beneath "innocent" in line 11. Some of the decorations are suggestive of human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY") but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

There are birds beneath "into the" in line 7—flying to the right—and beneath "you drive" in line 15—hovering and facing forward, with wings outspread, on a vine. The latter bird may be an eagle. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "seated" in line 9 and above "their" in line 11) but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

The text is crowded with a mixture of interlinear vegetation, animals, birds, and human figures.
