The block letters of the title are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S" and "Y" of "THURSDAY") and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird or human figure. Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "seated" in line 9 and above "their" in line 11) or human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY") but are equally likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

lg.l: Twas on a Holy Thursday their innocent faces clean
The children walking two & two in red & blue & green
(snow
Grey headed beadles walkd before with wands as white as
Till into the high dome of Pauls they like Thames waters flow
O what a multitude they seemd these flowers of London town
Seated in companies they sit, with radiance all their own
The hum of multitudes was there but multitudes of lambs
Thousands of little boys & girls raising their innocent hands
Now like a mighty wind they raise to heaven the voice of song
Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heaven among
Beneath them sit the aged men wise guardians of the poor
Then cherish pity, lest you drive an angel from your door

desc.objtitle:
The Lamb,
Object 19 (Bentley 8, Erdman 8, Keynes 8)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a grassy landscape, a nude boy (or perhaps wearing transparent tights) with short hair stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep—some grazing, some standing, some lying down. The boy reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "little lamb" of the text—with his hands. Behind the flock are a leafy oak tree with a large trunk (left) and a cottage or barn (right) with a doorway or window. On its thatched roof perch two birds, often identified as doves. Two slender trees, one on each side, frame the plate. Both trees are intertwined with vines that sprout leaves and several loopy tendrils. The tree branches meet and intertwine at the top, creating an arch between the title and the text of the poem. Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.

component.illusobjdesc: In a grassy landscape, a nude boy (or perhaps wearing transparent tights) with short hair stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep. He reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands.

In a grassy landscape, a nude boy (or perhaps wearing transparent tights) stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep—some grazing, some standing, some lying down. The boy reaches out to touch(?) the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands.
The green coloring on the ground suggests grass.
Behind the flock of sheep is a leafy oak tree with a large trunk (left).

Two slender trees, one on each side, frame the plate. Both trees are intertwined with vines that sprout several loopy tendrils. The tree branches meet and intertwine at the top, creating an arch between the title and the text of the poem. Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.
On the roof of a cottage or barn perch two birds, often identified as doves.
Behind the flock of sheep is a cottage or barn (right) with a thatched(?) roof and a doorway or window. A slight shadow cuts diagonally across the top left corner of the door or window.
A slight shadow cuts diagonally across the top left corner of the door or window in the cottage. Shadows also appear at the base of each tree, and between the right-hand tree and the plate’s edge.

The blue areas below the tree and around the upper part of the plate suggest sky, perhaps with clouds around the text and title. Pink washes surrounding stanza one and extending down the left side of stanza two may suggest sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.

component.illusobjdesc: Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.

lg.l: Little Lamb who made thee
Dost thou know who made thee
Gave thee life & bid thee feed.
By the stream & o'er the mead;
Gave thee clothing of delight,
Softest clothing wooly bright;
Gave thee such a tender voice,
Making all the vales rejoice;
Little Lamb who made thee
Dost thou know who made thee
Little Lamb I'll tell thee,
Little Lamb Ill tell thee;
He is called by thy name,
For he calls himself a Lamb:
He is meek & he is mild,
He became a little child:
I a child & thou a lamb,
We are called by his name.
Little Lamb God bless thee,
Little Lamb God bless thee.

desc.objtitle:
The Chimney Sweeper,
Object 20 (Bentley 12, Erdman 12, Keynes 12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The illustration seems to depict chimney sweeper Tom Dacre's dream of liberation for himself and his fellow sweeps by an angel, who releases them from their "coffins of black" to run "naked" down a "green plain" and "wash in a river" (lines 14-18). Against a leafy background of plants or perhaps trees are twelve small figures. At bottom right a gowned adult bends forward, reaching toward a nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the coffins of the text. Across the rest of the bottom of the plate are nude figures standing or running with their arms raised in various positions. Two pairs are embracing. Behind the gowned adult a tree grows up the right margin.

component.illusobjdesc: At bottom right a gowned adult, presumably the liberating angel of the text, bends forward, reaching toward a nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the coffins of the text.

At bottom right a gowned adult reaches down toward a nude figure emerging from the earth or one of the "coffins" of the text. This small figure—probably a child—reaches up with the left arm to hold the adult's hand; the right arm is bent and braced against the coffin or earth. One leg is bent at the knee and planted on the ground. The child looks up to the adult.

The rectangular object under the child emerging (with the adult's help) from the earth may be a grave or, more probably, one of the "coffins" of the text. A dark shadow extends beneath the adult figure to the right.

A pair of nude figures stands with their arms raised at 135 degrees; they may be holding hands. They are most likely two of the liberated nude boys of Tom Dacre's dream in the text—"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).
Two standing figures embrace. These are presumably two of the naked liberated chimney sweepers of the text.

At bottom left there is a pair of nude figures (the sixth and seventh from the left) who seem to be running with their arms raised. The figure on the right may twist his head to look right. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text-"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).

At bottom left there is a pair of nude figures (the fourth and fifth from the left) who appear to face each other and embrace, with legs spread apart. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text.

At bottom left there is a trio of nude figures (the first, second and third from the left) who appear to be running with arms raised vertically or at 135 degrees. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text-"leaping laughing they run" (line 17).
A thin, leafy tree grows up the right margin, ending to the right of the fifth stanza of the poem.
Green washes below the group of liberated boys suggest the "green [i.e., grassy?] plain" of the text (line 17). Plants (a hedge?) or distant trees form the background.

Blue background washes (concentrated along the left margin and between several of the stanzas) indicate sky, and yellow and pink washes above the figures at left and the tree at right suggest sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: There are three figures associated with the title, a chimney sweeper carrying a bag on his back in the "C" of "Chimney" and two figures on the leaf above the "ee" in "Sweeper." A seated figure appears in the vegetation right of line 15. The capital letters of the title and the lower-case "y" have extravagant extensions with occasional leaves and perhaps flowers. The extension at the top of the "S" joins (or nearly touches) the vegetation in the right margin to wrap around the right end of the title and descend as a loopy vine in the right margin. Other bits of vine-like structures—some of them extensions of the marginal vegetation, some of letters in the text—fill the spaces between quatrains of text, while the tree and other vegetation in the right margin fill spaces at the ends of short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: In the "C" of "Chimney" in the title is a tiny figure that may be a right-facing chimney sweeper carrying a bag of soot.

Two figures appear above the "ee" of "Sweeper" in the title. The one on the left is seated, facing forward, legs slightly spread and with left arm raised. There may be an object, possible a hat, in this figure's raised left arm. The figure's right arm may be raised horizontally. The figure on the right reclines, probably facing left.
A small figure sits in the vegetation right of line 14. The figure faces left and has one arm raised horizontally and bent upward at the elbow.

The text and margins are busy with vegetative forms. The capital letters of the title and the lower-case "y" have extravagant extensions with occasional leaves and perhaps flowers. The extension at the top of the "S" joins (or nearly touches) the vegetation in the right margin to wrap around the right end of the title and descend as a loopy vine in the right margin. Other bits of vine-like structures—some of them extensions of the marginal vegetation, some of letters in the text—fill the spaces between quatrains of text, while the tree and other vegetation in the right margin fill spaces at the ends of short lines. The vegetation right of lines 15-16 may be a tree.

lg.l: When my mother died I was very young,
And my father sold me while yet my tongue,
Could scarcely cry weep weep weep weep.
So your chimneys I sweep & in soot I sleep.
Theres little Tom Dacre. who cried when his head
(That curl'd like a lambs back, was shav'd. so I said.
Hush Tom never mind it, for when your head's bare.
You know that the soot cannot spoil your white hair
And so he was quiet, & that very night.
As Tom was a sleeping he had such a sight,
That thousands of sweepers Dick. Joe Ned & Jack
Were all of them lock'd up in coffins of black,
And by came an Angel who had a bright key.
And he open'd the coffins & set them all free.
run
Then down a green plain leaping laughing they Lacking sufficient space for the word "run," Blake etched it above line 18 (line 17).
And wash in a river and shine in the Sun.
Then naked & white, all their bags left behind.
They rise upon clouds, and sport in the wind.
And the Angel told Tom if he'd be a good boy,
He'd have God for his father & never want joy.
And so Tom awoke and we rose in the dark
And got with our bags & our brushes to work.
Tho' the morning was cold, Tom was happy & warm
So if all do their duty, they need not fear harm.

desc.objtitle:
A Dream,
Object 21 (Bentley 26, Erdman 26, Keynes 26)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several varieties of vegetation fill spaces around the text and between stanzas. The initial "A" in the title sprouts a plant-like structure on the left, while a loopy vine-like extension dangles all the way down the left margin. The vegetation in the upper right margin—beside the "m" of "Dream" in the title—seems to be an arc of tasseled grass or grain that curves back over the title. Beneath it—opposite stanzas 1 and 2—are three or four clusters of flame-like leaves or tufts of grass. Below those are a bit of leafy vine (after line 11) and a branch or root of some sort (after line 14). In the lower right margin—opposite stanzas 4 and 5—is an odd tree(?) or perhaps a stump. In front of the tree stands a figure, robed, apparently wearing a hat, and holding a staff—probably the "watchman of the night" (line 18), the glow-worm of the text in human form. He is one of four small human figures on the plate. The other three are in the area of the title: lying propped on an elbow on the left stroke of the initial "A"; sitting, perhaps reading or writing, in the "D" of "Dream"; and floating or flying, with arms raised horizontally, between bits of vegetation beneath the "e" of "Dream." The animal life of the poem appears in similarly tiny forms in the margins: there could be an ant (the "Emmet" of line 5) or beetle to the right of line 5 and perhaps another ant crawling beneath the "her" in line 10, a worm or caterpillar nestled in the lower right sprigs of the vegetation right of line 7, and beetles(?) (lines 20-21) flying right of lines 6 and 19. A bird, perhaps an eagle, unmentioned in the text, spreads its wings above "dream" in line 3. Blue washes around the text indicate sky.

component.illusobjdesc: In front of the tree in the bottom right corner stands a figure, robed, wearing a hat, and holding a staff in his(?) right hand, a lantern(?) in his left—probably the "watchman of the night" (line 18), the glow-worm of the text in human form.

There are three tiny figures in the area of the title: one lying propped on an elbow on the left stroke of the initial "A"; a second sitting, facing left, probably reading or writing, in the "D" of "Dream"; and a third hovering or flying with arms raised horizontally between bits of vegetation beneath the "e" of "Dream."

The insect life of the poem appears in tiny forms in the margins: there could be an ant (the "Emmet" of line 5) or beetle crawling to the right of line 4 and perhaps another ant crawling beneath the "her" in line 10, a worm or caterpillar nestled in the lower right sprigs of the vegetation right of line 7, and perhaps beetles (lines 20-21) flying right of lines 6 and 19. The human figure lower right may be the anthropomorphic form of the "glow-worm" (line 16).
A bird, perhaps an eagle, soars upward just below the space between "A" and "Dream" in the title.

Several varieties of vegetation fill spaces around the text and between stanzas. The initial "A" in the title sprouts a plant-like structure on the left, while a loopy vine-like extension dangles all the way down the left margin. A further extension of this vine, or an independent vine, runs horizontally below the last stanza. The vegetation in the upper right margin—beside the "m" of "Dream" in the title—seems to be an arc of tasseled grass or grain that curves back over the title. Beneath it—opposite stanzas 1 and 2—are three or four clusters of flame-like leaves or tufts of grass. Below those are a bit of leafy vine (after line 11) and a branch or root of some sort (after line 14). In the lower right margin—opposite stanzas 4 and 5—is an odd tree(?) or perhaps a stump.
The watchman in the lower right corner may be holding a staff in his right hand and a second object—perhaps a lantern—in his left. He seems to be wearing a hat.
Blue washes around the text indicate sky.

lg.l: Once a dream did weave a shade.
O'er my Angel-guarded bed.
That an Emmet lost it's way,
Where on grass methought I lay.
Troubled wilderd and folorn"folorn": i.e., "forlorn".
Dark benighted travel-worn,
Over many a tangled spray.
All heart-broke I heard her say.
O my children! do they cry,
Do they hear their father sigh.
Now they look abroad to see,
Now return and weep for me.
Pitying I drop'd a tear;
But I saw a glow-worm ar;The last word ("near") did not print well. Only the right side of "a" and the final letter are visible. A mark appears where the upper part of "e" should be.
Who replied. What wailing wight
Calls the watchman of the night.
I am set to light the ground,
While the beetle goes his round:
Follow now the beetles hum,
Little wanderer hie thee home.

desc.objtitle:
The School Boy,
Object 22 (Bentley 53, Erdman 53, Keynes 53)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text are three boys playing a game (of marbles?) on the ground. To the right of the boys is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. On the vines are four other children: (bottom to top) one long-haired, nude figure of indeterminate gender stands with arms raised, two boys(?) climbing, and another boy(?) sitting and reading. In the left margin is another elaborate vine with a large bird perched or flying near its top, left of the first stanza. A figure stands in these vines, perhaps facing right, just left of the fourth stanza.

component.illusobjdesc: The short-haired boy wearing a shirt and breeches on the left kneels on the ground with his arm down, as if poised to shoot a marble in the game that he and the other children present are playing.
The short-haired boy in tights in the middle kneels, leaning forward, with his arms braced to support his weight. He looks down toward the hand of the boy to the left.

The right-most child—probably male—in the group below the text may wear a shirt and breeches. He is sitting, bending sharply forward with head and arms down. Though facing left, he appears to be looking down at the ground rather than at the game.

A long-haired, nude girl or boy stands at the intersection of two vines, perhaps in the process of climbing them (like the figure just above it). The left-facing figure's head is thrown sharply back, its arms are raised vertically to hold onto the vines above its head, and its weight is on its extended left leg.

A short-haired boy who may wear nude tights climbs in the intertwining vines that extend up the right margin. Facing forward and looking right, he raises his arms vertically to hold onto the vines over his head. His right leg is drawn up toward his body; his left leg is extended along the vine.
A child (in tights?), probably a boy though other identifying features are not shown, climbs the vine. His arms are raised vertically to cling to the vines over his head. His legs are spread wide.
Facing right, a child of indeterminate sex in tights sits in a curve at the top of a vine in the right margin. The child holds, and appears to be reading, a book.
A figure stands, probably gowned and facing right, in the tree left of the fourth stanza. The figure's left arm appears to be extended to the right.
A bird with long forked tail and wings partially spread perches in or flies amongst the vegetation to the left of the first stanza.

Behind the right-most figure below the text is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation—perhaps grass—and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. The vines have numerous tendrils and leaves and at least one large cluster of fruit, to the right of line 21.
Rooted at lower left, a slender tree with leaves extends up the left margin and ends opposite line 8(?). An intertwined vine climbs the tree, with one loop left of the fifth stanza.
Three children play a game, perhaps marbles. Four marbles are just barely visible on the ground beneath the right-most child.
Blue background washes above the children playing marbles suggest sky.
Shadows appear behind both tree trunks in the lower right corner of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal trees and vines. The first of these, upper left, descends in loops and supports a bird (considered here to be part of the main illustration). Tendrils from the vines in the right margin—part of the main illustration—are extended into some of the spaces left by short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal vines. The first of these, upper left, descends in loops and supports a bird (considered here to be part of the main illustration).

lg.l: I love to rise in a summer morn,
When the birds sing on every tree;
The distant huntsman winds his horn,
And the sky-lark sings with me.
O! what sweet company.
But to go to school in a summer morn,
O! it drives all joy away:
Under a cruel eye outworn.
The little ones spend the day,
In sighing and dismay.
Ah! then at times I drooping sit,
And spend many an anxious hour,
Nor in my book can I take delight,
Nor sit in learnings bower,
Worn thro' with the dreary shower.
How can the bird that is born for joy,
Sit in a cage and sing.
How can a child when fears annoy.
But droop his tender wing.
And forget his youthful spring.
O! father & mother, if buds are nip'd,
And blossoms blown away.
And if the tender plants are strip'd
Of their joy in the springing day,
By sorrow and cares dismay.
How shall the summer arise in joy.
Or the summer fruits appear. (troy
Or how shall we gather what griefs des
Or bless the mellowing year.
When the blasts of winter appear.

desc.objtitle:
Laughing Song,
Object 23 (Bentley 15, Erdman 15, Keynes 15)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Eight figures gather around a table that sits on grass against a wall of green vegetation. Five figures sit behind the table, away from the viewer; the female at far right extends her arm to hold a drinking glass that rests on the table. Near the ends of the table on the front side, two other figures sit in chairs that are turned sideways, facing one another. Each figure holds a glass on the table. Between them an eighth figure, a male in tights, stands facing away from the viewer. In upraised hands he holds a glass (right) and a plumed hat (left). The faces of all the figures on the far side of the table are visible. The three figures on the near side face away from the viewer toward the rest of the company. The text mentions "green woods," "meadows," and a "table" in "the shade" (lines 3, 7, 11-12). The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the slight shadows on the ground, lower right, and up the right side of the illustration.

component.illusobjdesc: At the center is a curly-haired male in tights standing poised and erect facing away from the viewer. He stands in contrapposto with his legs spread; his right leg is straight, his left is extended left, the foot held with its toes pointed. His arms are bent and raised vertically. In his right hand is a wine glass or cup, in his left a hat with a plume. In the context of the poem his actions suggest that he may be singing.

In front of the table and symmetrically placed near its opposite ends are two seated figures, both in chairs turned parallel with the table and toward the center. The figure at far left is a female with curly hair and wearing a long gown. Her left leg is extended slightly forward; her right leg is drawn back under her. Her right arm is extended to hold a glass that rests on the table. Her left arm rests on the back of her chair, and her body is twisted counterclockwise as if to face the female across the table from her.

In front of the table and symmetrically placed near its opposite ends are two seated figures, both in chairs turned parallel with the table and toward the center. The figure at far right is a short-haired male in tights. His left leg is extended forward and his foot is visible; his right leg is drawn back under him. His right arm is extended along the table surface to hold a glass; only the upper part of his left is visible near the back of the chair. His lower body faces left, with his torso facing forward and his head twisted clockwise to face the two females across the table.
Five figures are seated behind the table. The figure at far left seems to be a female in a hat with a round brim. She faces and stares forward.
Five figures are seated behind the table. Second from the left appears to be a female with short, curly hair.

Five figures are seated behind the table. Third from the left is a female with long, curly hair and wearing a gown. Her head is turned right. Her right arm is raised to 45 degrees, her left bent at the elbow.
Five figures are seated behind the table. Second from the right is a female in a high-waisted gown. Her hair is either short or pulled back. She faces forward but looks slightly right.

Five figures are seated behind the table. At far right is a female wearing a hat with a round brim. At the end of an outstretched right arm she holds a glass that rests on the table. She looks to the right.

Several figures gather around a table that sits on grass against a wall of green vegetation, probably trees. Though the vegetation is not clearly defined, the text mentions "meadows" and "green woods."
The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the dark shadows on the ground lower right that extend along the lower margin of the design and up the right side.

In front of the table, near each end, two figures sit in symmetrically-placed chairs turned parallel with the table. The chairs have backs and rear legs integrated into a single convex curve. The front leg of the chair on the right curves forward to balance the curve of the rear legs.
Four figures hold drinking glasses. Three rest on the table; the fourth is in the right hand of the central standing figure.
There is a plumed hat with a round brim in the left hand of the central standing figure. The women at far left and far right sitting behind the table also have on round-brimmed hats.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the decoration is marginal rather than strictly interlinear. Numerous birds, especially in the bottom margin, ornament areas around the text. There are a few decorative extensions on the letters of the title, notably the "L" and "h" of "Laughing," and there are vine-like tendrils in the right margin. There is an elaborate tendril with loops and an occasional leaf at the end of the last two lines and across the bottom.

component.illusobjdesc: Several birds of various sizes perch and fly on and among the vegetation. Around the title, to the left a bird with outspread wings ascends vertically; another glides over "Song"; and at the right a third dives. In the right margin, after "shade" (line 11), a tiny bird ascends steeply. The small winged creatures farther to the right may be two more birds or insects. Across the bottom of the plate are seven other birds (left to right): two flying above the vine, with outspread wings and the second with a forked tail, the right one ascending; below the vine a third, descending; a fourth, with forked tail, perching on the vine; to its right, above the vine a fifth bird flying, and below the vine, a sixth ascending and, finally, a seventh perching with wings raised.

There are a few decorative extensions on the letters of the title, notably the "L" and "h" of "Laughing," both with loops, and there are vine-like tendrils in the right margin. There is an elaborate tendril with loops and an occasional leaf at the end of the last two lines and across the bottom.
Blue and pink background washes concentrated around the right margin suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: When the green woods laugh with the voice of joy
And the dimpling stream runs laughing by,
When the air does laugh with our merry wit,
And the green hill laughs with the noise of it.
When the meadows laugh with lively green
And the grasshopper laughs in the merry scene,
When Mary and Susan and Emily,
With their sweet round mouths sing Ha, Ha, He,
When the painted birds laugh in the shade
Where our table with cherries and nuts is spread
Come live & be merry and join with me,
To sing the sweet chorus of Ha, Ha, He.

desc.objtitle:
NURSES Song Nurse's Song,
Object 24 (Bentley 24, Erdman 24, Keynes 24)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the bottom, under the (lower?) limb of a tree with a few leaves, seven children—four boys and three girls—hold hands and play, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. The two children furthest left stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth, between them. A matron-figure in hat and gown, evidently the nurse of the title, sits on the ground against the trunk and reads a book in her lap. To the right is a second, slimmer tree with a vine around its trunk. There are two "hills" (line 14) in the background with a notch between them. The coloring of the sky indicates a sunset (line 7), perhaps with a few clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Seven children hold hands and play vigorously, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. Clockwise from the left: The two children furthest left (a girl and a boy) stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth used in a game, between them; a girl raises her arms horizontally and faces right; a boy raises his arms higher, as does the long-haired girl to the right of him, whose leg is extended behind her; holding her hand, a boy runs left and reaches forward to hold the hand of another running or striding boy, left leg extended behind him, who raises his free left hand as he moves left and back, perhaps toward the opening between the pair furthest left. All the girls wear gowns; all the boys apparently wear tight-fitting garments. These are the "little ones" who "leaped & shouted & laugh'd" (line 17) and remonstrate with the nurse in the poem.

Facing right, a matron-figure in cap and gown, evidently the nurse of the title who remonstrates with the children of the poem, sits on the ground or a low seat against the trunk of a tree and reads a book that she holds in her lap.

On the left is the trunk of a tree whose lowermost branch, with a few leaves, spreads over the nurse who sits at the base of its trunk. On the right is a second, slimmer tree, with more leafy branches and a vine climbs its trunk. Between the trees is the grassy "green" of line 3.
There are two "hills" (line 14) in the background with a notch between them. The coloring of the sky suggests the sunset alluded to in the text, line 7, with a dark cloud above the rightmost hill.
The nurse reads a book that she holds in her lap.
A shadow, perhaps cast by the tree at left, falls along the lower border of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On this plate the interlinear designs are especially dense around the title, in the margins, and between the three stanzas. The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g." There are also three prominent leafy formations in this area: one at the top of the "S," another growing from the "N" of "Nurse's," and the third in the top left corner. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration dangles in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 5. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into what may be water. Between stanzas (after lines 6, 10, and 14) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vine-like structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin. Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," climbing the left stroke and sitting on a leaf at the end of the curling right stroke; one reaching downward through the following "u"; one leaning against the "S" of "Song" with head propped on one hand, elbow on knee; two beneath "Song" on the long horizontal descender of the "g" and one reclining, with right arm raised horizontally, on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 4. The far left end of the horizontal descender of the "g" may also bear a supine figure. Between the lines there are a few birdlike shapes.

component.illusobjdesc: Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation. Clockwise from top left: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," one (nude?) climbing the left stroke and the other sitting, facing right, on a leaf at the end of the curling right stroke; one hovering in the following "u," reaching downward; one facing left and leaning, with one leg drawn up, against the "S" of "Song"; on the end of the long horizontal descender of the "g," two reclining, the one on the left straddling the vegetation; one, arm raised, reclining on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 4 and another(?), who merges almost indistinguishably with the vegetation, seated in a contracted posture, on the leafy structure at the end of line 6. The far left end of the horizontal descender of the "g" may also bear a supine figure.
There are two or three birdlike shapes above "for it is" in line 11 and another above "hills" in the last line.

The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g." There are several long, slender leaves (the descender on the "g," for instance), and there are three other prominent leafy formations in this area: one at the top of the "S," another growing from the "N" of "Nurse's," and the third in the top left corner. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration dangles in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 6. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into what may be water. Between stanzas (after lines 6, 10, and 14) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vine-like structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin.
A few lines may represent water into which the branches of the willow descend.

lg.l: When the voices of children are heard on the green
And laughing is heard on the hill,
My heart is at rest within my breast
And every thing else is still
Then come home my children the sun is gone down
And the dews of night arise
Come come leave off play, and let us away
Till the morning appears in the skies
No no let us play, for it is yet day
And we cannot go to sleep
Besides in the sky, the little birds fly
And the hills are all coverd with sheep
Well well go & play till the light fades away
And then go home to bed
The little ones leaped & shouted & laugh'd
And all the hills ecchoed

desc.objtitle:
The Little Boy Lost,
Object 25 (Bentley 13, Erdman 13, Keynes 13)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the darkness, a small boy in a gown holds his arms out toward a triangle of light at the left. He is presumably the Little Boy lost, who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 10: i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 3, 5). A tree rises on the right and branches over the child's head.

component.illusobjdesc: In the darkness, a small boy in a gown and wearing a hat holds his arms out toward a triangle of light on the left. He is presumably the Little Boy lost.

A leafless tree grows on the right. A prominent root grows from the left side of the tree in the direction of the boy. Two branches extend toward the top right corner of the design; another extends above the child.
The boy wanders at night in the darkness.

A small boy holds his arms out toward a triangle of light at the left. The white triangle is surrounded with flame-like spiky radiance or beams of light. He is presumably the Little Boy lost, who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 10: i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 3, 5).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, four winged. The letters of the title sprout vegetative extensions, and there are other bits of vegetation amidst the angels (notably at the bottom), between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There are also two seated figures in the title letters, one facing left on the "L" of "Little" and one with raised arm in the "B" of "Boy." There may also be a third figure lying and facing right on the left side of the "B." There are four flying birds and a swan or duck among the lines of the title and the first stanza.

component.illusobjdesc: The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, all probably female. They are symmetrically arranged, two beside each stanza and two, aligned foot to foot, beneath. They all seem to be gowned, and the four in the right and left margins have wings. The two in the right margin have their arms at their sides; the two wingless figures below float or fly horizontally with one arm raised (with banners or flags of drapery arranged symmetrically); the lower figure in the left margin has its arms by its side; the upper figure on that side faces right, has its left arm raised vertically, and may be pointing to the scene above.

There are two figures sitting in the title letters, one facing left, with bent arm raised to its head, on the "L" of "Little," the other sitting with arm raised at about 135 degrees in the "B" of "Boy." There may also be a third figure lying on its side and facing right on the left side of the "B."

Four birds fly among the lines of the title and the first stanza: over "lost" in the title, over "where" and "going" in line 3, and after "fast" in line 4. There is a swan or duck above the "y" of "Boy."

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above most of the title. The "y" of "Boy" is extended, and an unattached clump of plant-like decoration surrounds the right end of the title. There are other bits of leafy (and/or flowery) vegetation around the two figures at the bottom, between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There is a particularly loopy, leafy tendril after line 6 and between the two stanzas.
Blue background washes indicate sky.

lg.l: Father, father, where are you going
O do not walk so fast.
Speak father. speak to your little boy
Or else I shall be lost,
The night was dark no father was there
The child was wet with dew.
The mire was deep, & the child did weep
And away the vapour flew

desc.objtitle:
The Little Boy Found,
Object 26 (Bentley 14, Erdman 14, Keynes 14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a landscape dominated by the trunks of three large trees, a long-haired adult figure, visually ambiguous but male according to the text, dressed in a high-waisted long gown holds the hand of a gowned child. The two figures look at one another as they walk forward, on grassy ground, toward the viewer. The child raises his right arm. The adult has a lighted ring around his head that suggests a halo, from which beams of light extend. The child appears to wear a hat, which also might suggest a halo. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 3-7).

component.illusobjdesc: A long-haired adult figure in a high-waisted long gown—visually ambiguous, though the reference to "God . . . like his father" (lines 5-6) suggests that he is male—walks beside a boy whose hand he holds (he holds his opposite arm by his side). If this is God, it is very probably Christ, given the similarities between this figure and several of Blake's other representations of Christ. Both feet are exposed; his left foot is forward. He has a lighted ring around his head that suggests a halo. He looks down toward the boy.

The two figures walk forward toward the viewer. A gowned male child with short, curly hair wearing a halo-like hat walks forward toward the viewer beside a similarly dressed adult whose hand he holds and up at whom he looks. The little boy steps forward with his right leg. The child raises his left arm at 45 degrees, his right at 135 degrees. Dark wash above the child's head suggests a halo-like hat. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 3-7).

A dark landscape (though lighter than other copies)—the "lonely dale" (line 9) of the text—is dominated by three large and ominous tree trunks—two left and one right—without visible leaves or other vegetation except possibly reeds behind the figures and the suggestion of grass below.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned angelic spirit with long hair flies with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. Her gown and a loop of drapery right of her back trail behind her. The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title and into the left margin; another group of detached vegetative decorations fills the space below the poem and up the right margin to the angelic spirit. Another loopy vine descends in the left margin. Blue background washes suggest sky.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned angelic spirit, probably female, floats with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. She looks sharply upward, as if at the design above. Her gown and a loop of drapery right of her back trail behind her. This may be the child's "mother" (line 8) to whom he is led.

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title. The capital letters of the title all have such extensions. The "y" of "Boy" extends far to the left and down the left margin, and the vertical stroke of the "d" of "found" is extravagantly extended to fill the space above the angel. Another cluster of vine-like decorations begins in the right margin in front of the legs of the angel and extends downward into the space below the poem.
Blue washes around the text and designs suggest sky.

lg.l: The little boy lost in the lonely fen,
Led by the wand'ring light,
Began to cry, but God ever nigh,
Appeard like his father in white.
He kissed the child & by the hand led
And to his mother brought,
Who in sorrow pale thro' the lonely dale
Her little boy weeping sought.

desc.objtitle:
Night,
Object 27 (Bentley 20, Erdman 20, Keynes 20)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A slender tree with leafy branches grows up the right margin, bends under and around the left end of the title—whose lettering harmonizes with the surrounding foliage—and curves back over it. A second tree, much smaller, is also rooted lower right; its branches cross behind the larger tree above the angel opposite "nest" in line 19. A second branch of the larger tree continues up the right side of the plate to complete the circle around the title. Several leafy branches extend left into the spaces left by short lines of the poem. The tree is loosely encircled by a leafy vine whose termination, perhaps a little beyond the point where the tree bends left, is unclear. Just left of the trees, lower right, a lion lies in front of a hill or mound covered in grass. There are winged angelic figures in the tree, one standing with wings outspread at top right (faint in this copy), a second sitting with wings folded on a branch beneath the first, and a third hovering just above the lion's den. Two birds perch on a branch right of line 6. In the left margin are other figures and objects (bottom to top): one gowned, standing on the grassy ground and facing the third stanza; just above that, a figure with one arm raised; another, arms raised vertically, standing on a sphere (the sun or moon?); just above that another, smaller, with wings and arms outspread. All the figures may be the angels described in the text (Object 27, stanzas 2-3; Object 28, stanza 1). Above the top figure on the left, left of line 6, is another sphere (the sun or moon?); scattered across this same space in the left margin are several dots, perhaps stars. Blue background washes suggest sky.

component.illusobjdesc: There are winged, gowned angelic figures in the tree, one standing with wings or arms outspread at top right; a second, facing right, sitting with wings folded on a branch beneath the first; and a third, with arms raised horizontally, hovering or standing on one foot just above the lion's den.

In the left margin are other figures (bottom to top): one gowned, standing and facing right toward the third stanza; just above that, a figure with one arm raised; another standing, arms raised vertically, on a sphere (the sun or moon?); just above that another, with wings and arms outspread.

Rooted at bottom right, a slender tree with leafy branches grows up the right margin, bends under and around the left end of the title—whose lettering harmonizes with the surrounding foliage—and curves back over it. A second tree, much smaller, is also rooted lower right; its branches cross behind the larger tree above the angel opposite "nest" in line 19. A second branch of the larger tree continues up the right side of the plate to complete the circle around the title. Several leafy branches extend left into the spaces left by short lines of the poem. The tree is loosely encircled by a leafy vine whose termination, perhaps a little beyond the point where the tree bends left, is unclear. Some indeterminate vegetation extends in an arch over a hill or mound, lower right.
A strip of grass runs across the bottom of the plate; at right it covers a hill or bank.
A grass-covered hill or mound rises behind the tree and lion at lower right. This formation may be partially composed of arching vegetation.
Two birds perch on a branch right of line 6.
A lion lies facing forward, perhaps sleeping, in front of the hill at lower right.

In the left margin are two small circles, probably representing spheres, one above the figures and the other beneath the feet of the second figure from the top. One may be the moon and the other the sun. Between the two spheres are several scattered dots that may represent stars.
Blue background washes suggest sky.

lg.l: Night

component.illusobjdesc: The style of lettering in the title integrates it into the tree.

lg.l: The sun descending in the west.
The evening star does shine.
The birds are silent in their nest.
And I must seek for mine,
The moon like a flower.
In heavens high bower;
With silent delight.
Sits and smiles on the night.
Farewell green fields and happy groves.
Where flocks have took delight;
Where lambs have nibbled, silent moves
The feet of angels bright;
Unseen they pour blessing,
And joy without ceasing,
On each bud and blossom.,
And each sleeping bosom.
They look in every thoughtless nest,
Where birds are coverd warm;
They visit caves of every beast,
To keep them all from harm;
If they see any weeping.
That should have been sleeping
They pour sleep on their head
And sit down by their bed.

desc.objtitle:
Night (continued),
Object 28 (Bentley 21, Erdman 21, Keynes 21)

objnote.p: Several letters in the final six lines of the text were overwritten by Blake in pen and ink. In the last line, "As I", etched on the copperplate as the first two words in the line, have been changed to "And".

illustration.illusobjdesc: A large tree, with a leafy vine lower left, grows up the left margin, while its long, leafy branches extend above and behind (as it were) the text well into the right margin. On the ground, in front of a backdrop of plants, five gowned female(?) figures stand in two groups. To the right, just under the branches, one female faces left and points or gestures left with her upraised left arm as she turns to look at her companion, who faces forward but looks left toward her companion. The heads of both figures are circled by white spheres, suggesting halos from which beams of radiance extend. To the left, close to the tree trunk, stand three other females, perhaps walking. White areas around their heads suggest halos. The left-most figure has her arms crossed and looks right. The one in the middle, who seems to have long hair, looks forward and bends her right arm upward; she holds an indistinguishable object in her right hand. The one to the right looks left and holds a harp or lyre by her side in her left hand. In the vine-encircled tree trunk in the left margin are two other gowned female(?) figures. To the left of the third stanza on this plate, a gowned figure hovers beside the tree trunk. To the left of the first stanza, a second figure may face left, though the position of the head is unclear in this copy. The seven(?) figures collectively may be the angels mentioned in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: Five gowned female(?) figures stand in two groups. To the right, just under the branches, one female faces left and points or gestures left with her upraised left arm as she turns to look at her companion, who faces forward but looks left toward her companion. The heads of both figures are circled by white spheres, suggesting halos from which beams of radiance extend. To their left, close to the tree trunk, stand three other females, perhaps walking. White areas around their heads suggest halos. The left-most figure has her arms crossed and looks right. The one in the middle, who seems to have long hair, looks forward and bends her right arm upward; she holds an indistinguishable object in her right hand. The one to the right looks left and holds a harp by her side in her left hand. These may be the angels mentioned in the text (stanzas 2-3, Object 27; stanza 1, Object 28).
The rightmost figure in the group of three females holds a harp or lyre by her side in her left hand.

In the tree trunk in the left margin are two gowned female(?) figures, perhaps the angels mentioned in the text. To the left of the third stanza, a gowned figure hovers beside the tree trunk. To the left of the first stanza, a second figure may face left, though the position of the head is unclear in this copy.

A large tree, with a leafy vine lower left, grows up the left margin, while its long, leafy branches extend above and behind (as it were) the text well into the right margin. Five figures stand on the grass against a backdrop of plants or other vegetation.
A shadow extends along the lower margin, narrowing as moves toward the bottom right corner.
Blue-gray background washes suggest sky.

lg.l: When wolves and tygers howl for prey
They pitying stand and weep;
Seeking to drive their thirst away,
And keep them from the sheep.
But if they rush dreadful;
The angels most heedful,
Recieve each mild spirit.
New worlds to inherit.
And there the lions ruddy eyes,
Shall flow with tears of gold;
And pitying the tender cries,
And walking round the fold:
Saying: wrath by his meekness
And by his health. sickness.
Is driven away.
From our immortal day.
And now beside thee bleating lamb.
I can lie down and sleep;
Or think on him who bore thy name.
Graze after thee and weep.The fourth letter of the first word has been overwritten in pen and ink to clearly indicate the letter "z".
For wash'd in lifes river,
My bright mane for ever.
Shall shine like the gold.
And guard o'er the fold.The first two words etched on the plate, "As I", have been overwritten by Blake in pen and ink to change these two words to a single word, "And".
